docs.lead_paragraph: HAVING children is viewed as so integral a part of adulthood that couples who are childless by choice are sometimes viewed with suspicion or disdain. They may be accused of being self-centered and uncaring, as if not having children is a sign of a larger emotional problem. Yet research on childless couples shows little basis for those accusations. Those studies indicate that, on the whole, people who are childless by choice report being more happily married than people who have children, according to Dr. Jay Belsky, a professor of human development and family studies at Pennsylvania State University. His interpretation is that children may keep unhappily married couples together longer.
